The circulatory system in amphibians and mammals is similar in many ways, but there are a few key differences.

Amphibians have a three-chambered heart, which means that they have two atria and one ventricle. The ventricle is partially divided, which allows for some separation of oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood. However, some mixing of blood occurs in the ventricle, which can result in lower oxygen levels in the blood.

Mammals, on the other hand, have a four-chambered heart, which means that they have two atria and two ventricles. This allows for complete separation of oxygen-rich and oxygen-poor blood, resulting in higher oxygen levels in the blood.

Another difference between the circulatory systems of amphibians and mammals is the role of the skin in gas exchange. In amphibians, the skin plays a significant role in gas exchange, allowing them to breathe through their skin in addition to their lungs. This is because their skin is thin and moist, which allows oxygen to diffuse through it easily. In mammals, gas exchange occurs primarily in the lungs.

Overall, the circulatory system in mammals is more efficient at delivering oxygen to the body's tissues compared to amphibians. However, amphibians have adapted to their environment with their three-chambered heart and ability to breathe through their skin.
